articles.headline: In State of the Union, Obama Sets an Ambitious Agenda
articles.snippet: President Obama defended an activist federal government and challenged Republicans to support him on education, child care and middle-class tax breaks.
articles.abstract: President Obama defended an activist federal government and challenged Republicans to support him on education, child care and middle-class tax breaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama claimed credit on Tuesday for an improving economy and defiantly told his Republican adversaries in Congress to “turn the page” by supporting an expensive domestic agenda aimed at improving the fortunes of the middle class.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Google and Fidelity Put $1 Billion Into SpaceX
articles.snippet: Google and Fidelity have invested in the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites.
articles.abstract: Google and Fidelity have invested in the rocketry company founded by Elon Musk, in part to further Google’s goal of extending the Internet’s reach through satellites.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google likes its ambitions sky high. This time, it has gone a little further.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: From Gluten-Free Beer to Kombucha, Alcohol Options for Health-Conscious Drinkers
articles.snippet: The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices.
articles.abstract: The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: For social drinkers seeking freedom from guilt, gluten or a hangover, the list of beverage options is growing longer.

articles.headline: Behind Drop in Oil Prices, Washington’s Hand
articles.snippet: The Nixon administration laid the foundation of a policy that developed the technology to produce American shale oil.
articles.abstract: The Nixon administration laid the foundation of a policy that developed the technology to produce American shale oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did the United States kill OPEC?

articles.headline: Safety Unit Broadens Its Scrutiny of a Ford Recall
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s new administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, has ordered a review of a 2013 recall of Ford’s biggest pickup trucks.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s new administrator, Mark R. Rosekind, has ordered a review of a 2013 recall of Ford’s biggest pickup trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week after the nation’s top auto regulator warned automakers that he would be more vigilant on safety, his agency has taken the unusual move of revisiting the 2013 recall of Ford’s biggest pickup trucks.
articles.byline: By Christopher Jensen and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: Bold Call to Action in Obama’s State of the Union, Even if No Action Is Likely
articles.snippet: Despite his party’s losses in the recent elections, President Obama laid out an expansive agenda as if he were the one who had triumphed.
articles.abstract: Despite his party’s losses in the recent elections, President Obama laid out an expansive agenda as if he were the one who had triumphed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Near the end of his State of the Union address, President Obama noted, “I have no more campaigns to run.” A few Republicans in the audience cheekily applauded.

articles.headline: U.S. Outpost in Cuba to Step Out of the Shadows
articles.snippet: A building in Havana that has long been a center of intrigue and was once the American Embassy will again serve its diplomatic purpose amid the new détente with Cuba.
articles.abstract: A building in Havana that has long been a center of intrigue and was once the American Embassy will again serve its diplomatic purpose amid the new détente with Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Fidel Castro called the building a “nest of spies,” routinely marshaling tens of thousands of people to protest at its doorstep. His government even made a television mini-series with what it called images of American diplomats lurking in a forest nearby, dropping off suspicious bags and marking benches in acts of espionage.

articles.headline: Century Later, the ‘Chinatown’ Water Feud Ebbs
articles.snippet: Los Angeles began taking water from the Owens Valley nearly a century ago, inspiring the movie “Chinatown.” But the fight that ensued may soon be over.
articles.abstract: Los Angeles began taking water from the Owens Valley nearly a century ago, inspiring the movie “Chinatown.” But the fight that ensued may soon be over.
articles.lead_paragraph: OWENS LAKE, Calif. — For 24 years, traveling across the stark and dusty moonscape of what once was a glimmering 110-square-mile lake framed by snow-covered mountains, Ted Schade was a general in the Owens Valley water wars with Los Angeles. This was where Los Angeles began taking water for its own use nearly a century ago, leaving behind a dry lake bed that choked the valley with dust, turning it into one of the most polluted parts of the nation.

articles.headline: At Risk of Fragmenting, Yemen Poses Dangers to U.S.
articles.snippet: The chaos could provide greater opportunities both for Iran and Al Qaeda, whose Yemeni branch claimed responsibility for one of the terrorist attacks in Paris this month.
articles.abstract: The chaos could provide greater opportunities both for Iran and Al Qaeda, whose Yemeni branch claimed responsibility for one of the terrorist attacks in Paris this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only months ago, American officials were still referring to Yemen’s negotiated transition from autocracy to an elected president as a model for post-revolutionary Arab states.
